FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 31A.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby authorized and established in and for the township the
Voorhees Township Fire Department which shall consist of such officers,
firefighters and emergency medical service (“EMS”) providers as hereinafter
prescribed.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.02 MISSION STATEMENT.
   The Township Fire Department is committed to exceeding the expectations of
the community it serves while providing professional firefighting and emergency
medical services and creating a safe environment through public education.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
PAID MEMBERS OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 31A.15 QUALIFICATIONS.
   Qualifications for paid members of the Fire Department shall be as set forth
in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-9.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.16 OFFICERS.
   The Fire Department officers shall consist of the Township Fire and
Emergency Services Director as set forth in Ordinance No. 296-17 of the
township for a period as determined by the Mayor and Township Committee and
thereafter shall consist of a Fire Chief, two Deputy Fire Chiefs, three
Battalion Fire Chiefs, and six Fire Captains. The terms of office shall be as
set forth in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-17.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.17 DUTIES OF TOWNSHIP FIRE AND EMERGENCY SERVICES DIRECTOR.
   The duties of the Township Fire and Emergency Services Director shall be as
set forth in Ordinance No. 296-17 of the township and as set forth in §
31A.18(A).
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.18 DUTIES OF OTHER OFFICERS.
   (A)   Duties of the Fire Chief. The Fire Chief shall be the head of the
Township Fire Department and shall be directly responsible to the Township
Committee for the Fire Department’s efficiency and day-to-day operations.
      (1)   The Fire Chief shall at the scene of a fire or rescue call, or
otherwise have sole and absolute control of and command at the exclusion of all
others in the Fire Department. He shall cause the arrangement of fire engineers
and placement of its apparatus at a fire and cause it to be used in such a
manner as will protect lives and property and extinguish most quickly and
effectively. He shall examine periodically the condition of the fire apparatus,
fire houses and all the property belonging to the Fire Department and shall
report the same in its condition to Township Committee in December of each year
which report shall be accompanied by a statement of the number of fire and
rescue calls that have occurred in the preceding year and the number of fires
attended by him or in his absence the Deputy Chief and such other information
necessary to advise Township Committee of the operation of the Fire Department.
      (2)   Pursuant to policies established by the Township Committee, the
Fire Chief shall:
         (a)   Have the general supervision of the Fire Department at all
times;
         (b)   Administer and enforce rules and regulations of the Fire
Department and any special emergency directors for the disposition and
discipline of the Fire Department and its members;
         (c)   Exercise and discharge the functions, powers and duties of the
Fire Department;
         (d)   Prescribe the duties and assignments of all members and
officers;
         (e)   Delegate such authority as may be deemed necessary for the
efficient operation of the Fire Department to be exercised under the Fire
Chief’s direction and supervision; and
         (f)   Report at least monthly to the Director of Public Safety in such
form as shall be prescribed on the operation of the Fire Department during the
preceding month and make such other reports as may be requested by the Director
of Public Safety.
   (B)   Duties of the Deputy Chiefs. The Fire Department shall have such
number of Deputy Chiefs as determined by Township Committee. The Deputy Chiefs
shall be subordinate to the command of the Fire Chief. In the absence of the
Fire Chief, the Deputy Chief shall act as the Fire Chief. The duties of the
Deputy Chiefs are as follows:
      (1)   Assist the Chief with the duties and responsibilities as prescribed
above.
      (2)   Be responsible for the maintenance of all equipment and apparatus
and make recommendations to the Fire Chief for replacement.
      (3)   Assist the Fire Chief in preparing the annual operating and capital
improvement budget.
   (C)   Duties of the Battalion Chiefs. The Fire Department shall have such
number of Battalion Chiefs as determined by Township Committee. The Battalion
Chiefs shall be subordinate to the command of the Deputy Chief. The duties of
the Battalion Chiefs are as follows:
      (1)   The Battalion Chiefs, under the control of the Fire Chief, always
has charge of the department members and apparatus. He or she shall, under the
same supervision, direct the operation of the Captains of the Fire Department
in the performance of their duties and enforce the rules of the Fire Department
in accordance with the laws adopted by the Township Committee. He or she shall
see that all members are trained and equipped to perform their duties when
called upon. Upon returning to the headquarters, he or she shall see that the
roll is called, absentees noted and a written report of such promptly submitted
to the Fire Chief. He or she shall report to the Fire Chief all fires or alarms
of fires, using the form adopted for that purpose.
      (2)   He or she shall report all needed repairs to the Deputy Chief but
shall have no power to alter any of the apparatus without the permission of the
Fire Chief. At a fire, the position of the Battalion Chief shall be at the
Incident Command Post of the fire directing the members of the Fire Department.
   (D)   Duties of the Captains. The Fire Department shall have such number of
Captains as determined by Township Committee. The Captain shall be subordinate
to the command of the Battalion Chief. In the absence of the Battalion Chief,
the Captain shall act as the Battalion Chief. The duties of the Captain are as
follows:
      (1)   The Captains, under the control of the Battalion Chief, always has
charge of the department apparatus. He or she shall, under the same
supervision, direct the operation of the apparatus of the Fire Department in
the performance of their duties and enforce the rules of the Fire Department in
accordance with the laws adopted by the Township Committee. He or she shall see
that the apparatus is safely returned to the Fire Department headquarters, that
nothing has been lost or mislaid while responding to an alarm and that nothing
has been taken from the apparatus while at headquarters. He or she shall report
to the Battalion Chief all those who fail to respond when called upon to clean
apparatus or turn out for drill practice. He or she shall see that the
companies clean and replace in order all the apparatus belonging to it before
leaving the Fire Department. He or she shall require members to wash and hang
up the hose when dry to restore same to the apparatus. Upon returning to the
headquarters, he or she shall see that the roll is called, absentees noted and
a written report of such promptly submitted to the Battalion Chief. He or she
shall report to the Fire Chief all fires or alarms of fires, using the form
adopted for that purpose, through the chain of command.
      (2)   He or she shall report all needed repairs to the Battalion Chief
but shall have no power to alter any of the apparatus without the permission of
the Fire Chief. At a fire, the position of the Captain shall be at the origin
of the fire, directing the members of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.19 APPOINTMENT OF FIREFIGHTERS AND EMS PROVIDERS.
   All paid members of the Fire Department shall be appointed by the Township
Committee in accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-7 et seq., N.J.A.C. 4a:1 et seq.
and the terms of this chapter.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.20 CONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Any paid employees serving as a member in good standing of the now dissolved
Voorhees Fire District at the time of its dissolution shall continue to serve
in such position with the Township Fire Department subject to the terms of this
chapter, except with regard to any disciplinary matters that were pending by
the now dissolved Voorhees Fire District against such member.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.21 PRIORITY OF ELIGIBILITY FOR INITIAL APPOINTMENT.
   All paid positions of the Fire Department shall be filled in accordance with
the priority of eligibility set forth in N.J.S.A. 40A:14-10.1a.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.22 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT FOR PAID MEMBERS.
   Residency requirements for appointments for paid members of the Fire
Department shall be in accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-9.2.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.23 AGE REQUIREMENT FOR PAID MEMBERS.
   Age requirements for appointments for paid members of the Fire Department
shall be in accordance with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-12.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.24 PROMOTIONS OF PAID MEMBERS.
   The promotions of paid members of the Fire Department shall be in accordance
with N.J.S.A. 40A:14-9.4.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.25 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   Each person appointed as a paid member of the Fire Department shall first
serve a probationary period of not less than one year from the date of
appointment. During the probationary period, he or she shall be designated as a
probationary member. At the termination of the probationary period, the
appointment of the member shall become final upon the recommendation of the
Fire Chief, as the case may be and the consent of the Director of Public
Safety. However, the Township Committee, for good cause shown, by resolution
may waive the probationary period or any part thereof for any appointee who has
had previous experience as a firefighter and who may otherwise meet the
qualifications as set forth in this chapter or the laws of the state.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.26 DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   Disciplinary action shall be taken against paid members of the Fire
Department in accordance with N.J.A.C. 4a:2 et seq. and the rules and
regulations adopted by Township Committee.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.27 HOURS OF DUTIES OF PAID MEMBERS.
   (A)   Each member of the Fire Department shall devote his or her entire time
and attention to the duties of the Fire Department, subject to the laws of this
state, the rules and regulations adopted by Township Committee and the
applicable employment contract or collective bargaining agreement then in force
with the township with respect to numbers and hours.
   (B)   No paid member of the Fire Department shall work or render services
for any wage salary or other compensation, other than for the Fire Department,
unless he or she first obtains written approval therefor from the Fire Chief,
which approval shall be granted only when the Fire Chief is reasonably certain
that such work or services shall not be hazardous or hamper the proper and
efficient performance of his or her official fire duties.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.28 COMPENSATION.
   The compensation of the paid Fire Chief, officers and members of the
Township Fire Department shall be determined by the Township Committee by
ordinance as applicable or pursuant to an employment agreement or collective
bargaining agreement negotiated between the township and officers or members,
as the case may be.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
VOLUNTEER MEMBERS OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 31A.40 OFFICERS.
   The number of Volunteer Officers within the Department shall be proposed by
the Fire Chief and approved by Township Committee with the intention to meet
the needs of the Department.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.41 MEMBERS.
   There shall be such volunteer members of the Fire Department as approved by
the Fire Chief and subject to this chapter.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.42 CONTINUANCE OF SERVICE.
   Any volunteer serving as a member in good standing of the now dissolved
Voorhees Fire District at the time of its dissolution shall continue to serve
with the Township Fire Department subject to the terms of this chapter, except
with regard to any disciplinary matters that were pending by the now dissolved
Voorhees Fire District against such member.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.43 QUALIFICATIONS.
   No applicant shall be eligible to become a volunteer member of the Fire
Department unless such person shall possess the following qualifications:
   (A)   Be at least 18 years of age, unless said member is applying for a
Junior or Explorer position.
   (B)   Be a citizen of the United States.
   (C)   Satisfactorily complete a physical fitness performance test approved
by the Fire Department.
   (D)   Be physically fit to perform the duties of a firefighter, said fitness
to be evidenced by a certificate to that effect, made by a practicing physician
of the state approved by the Fire Department.
   (E)   Be subject to a criminal and motor vehicle record check.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.44 MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION; APPROVAL.
   (A)   Any applicant seeking to join the Fire Department shall make
application thereto.
   (B)   After application has been made, the applicant will follow the steps
prescribed by the Department’s policies.
   (C)   After completion of all the prescribed steps in the Department’s
policy, the name of the applicant shall be submitted to the Fire Chief for
approval. After approval by the Fire Chief, the name of the applicant shall be
presented to Township Committee for confirmation.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.45 MEMBERSHIP ROLL; IDENTIFICATION.
   (A)   The names of the volunteer officers and members shall be written upon
the membership roll maintained by the Township Clerk.
   (B)   Each volunteer officer and member shall be given a badge and photo
identification card as evidence of membership. The badge and photo
identification shall be surrendered to the Fire Chief when demanded or whenever
the member is under charges involving moral turpitude or negligent duty or, for
any cause, shall cease to be an active firefighter.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.46 PROBATIONARY PERIOD.
   Any volunteer shall be classified as a probationary member for a period of
not less than one year from appointment. During the probationary period he or
she shall be known as a probationary member. At the termination of the
probationary period, the appointment shall become final upon recommendation of
the Fire Chief with the consent of the Director of Public Safety. However, the
Township Committee, for good cause, by resolution may waive the probationary
period or any part thereof for any appointee who had previous experience as a
firefighter and who otherwise meets the qualifications as set forth in this
chapter and the laws of the state.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.47 DISCIPLINARY ACTION.
   Any volunteer officer or member of the Fire Department who shall refuse or
voluntarily neglect to obey or execute any order from the Fire Department at
any firematic function or who shall violate or willfully neglect or refuse to
be controlled, governed or managed by any of the rules and regulations of the
Fire Department that may be adopted from time to time, as herein provided,
shall be subject to suspension or expulsion from the Fire Department in such
manner and upon such hearing or trial as may be prescribed or provided by the
rules and regulations of the Fire Department. The suspension or expulsion of
any member shall be subject to the approval of the Mayor and Township
Committee.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.48 CHARGES INVOLVING MORAL TURPITUDE, NEGLECT OF DUTY OR INSUBORDINATION;
APPEALS.
   All charges for offenses involving moral turpitude or neglect of duties or
insubordination while on duty as a firefighter or firematic function that may
be proferred against any volunteer officer or member of the Fire Department
shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the Department.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.49 MONTHLY STIPEND.
   Any volunteer officer or member of the Fire Department shall be entitled to
a monthly allowance that is set by the Chief of the Department and approved by
Township Committee. In addition, to be eligible to receive the monthly
allowance, each member must attend the minimum training sessions as set forth
by the Chief of the Department. Should any member be unavailable to attend a
training due to a conflict with their work schedule, they will be afforded the
opportunity to attend a make-up session to be coordinated with the Department
Training Officer. Advance permission from the Department Training Officer will
be required for members to receive credit for attending outside training
classes. The accumulated monies for each month shall be paid to the volunteer
member following the first Township Committee meeting of the following month.
In no event shall payments received by a volunteer officer or member equal or
exceed the limitations set forth in the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act as may
be amended from time to time, any IRS or State Department of Treasury rules or
regulations governing payments to volunteers or any guideline issued by the
State Department of Labor, taking into account also any non-financial benefits
received by said volunteer.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.50 CONSTRUAL OF PAYMENTS.
   The payments set forth in §
31A.51 shall constitute reimbursement for various expenses which may be
incurred by the members of the Fire Department in the faithful performance of
their duties [and] shall not be considered as salary.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.51 YEARLY CLOTHING ALLOWANCE.
   All volunteer officers and members of the Fire Department shall, regardless
of the number of the actual alarms responded to, be entitled to a yearly
clothing allotment as is fixed on an annual basis by Township Committee and in
accordance with the Fire Department uniform policy.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.52 LOSAP.
   Eligible volunteer officers and members are entitled to take part in the
Length of Service Awards Program (“LOSAP”) in accordance with applicable law,
rules and regulations.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.53 LIFE INSURANCE POLICY.
   Any volunteer officer or member of the Fire Department is eligible for
continued life insurance coverage which had been established by the now
dissolved VFD.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17)
§ 31A.54 VERIFICATION OF ATTENDANCE.
   The Fire Chief shall institute a verification procedure for the verification
of attendance which shall be approved annually by the Township Committee. Such
procedure shall include, but shall not be limited to requirements that each
firefighter personally sign a roster or an approved witnessed absentee roster
at the completion of and after each alarm or station duty indicating his or her
attendance at same, with such signatures to be witnessed by the officer in
charge; each member of the Fire Department shall maintain on file a specimen of
his or her signature; and the forms utilized in recording the attendance for
each call or duty shall be subject to the random and periodic audit under the
direction of the Fire Chief. These verification procedures will affect all
volunteer members of the Fire Department. Volunteer officers will be
responsible to the Fire Chief to verify their attendance at each call and
station duty.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.55 EXECUTION OF WAIVERS.
   No volunteer officer or member of the Fire Department shall be entitled to
any payment hereunder until he or she shall have first executed a waiver to be
prepared under the direction of the Township Clerk, waiving any and all claims
to pension, civil service or employment status of any kind whatsoever as a
result of receiving payments under this chapter.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
GENERAL PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO PAID AND VOLUNTEER MEMBERS
§ 31A.70 OATH OF OFFICE.
   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office and within five days
after appointment, each officer or member of the Fire Department shall take and
subscribe an oath or affirmation to faithfully and impartially discharge duties
of his or her appointment as an officer or member of the Fire Department in
accordance with the statutes of this state relating to the oath to be taken.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.71 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the officers and members of the Fire Department
shall be as prescribed by the laws of this state and such rules and regulations
as may now or hereafter be adopted by the Township Committee and the Fire
Department. All members of the Fire Department shall have the power to serve
and execute all processes issued by the Fire Department, Fire Chief and
Director of Public Safety in accordance with the laws of this state.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)
§ 31A.72 ALARMS.
   (A)   All members of the Township Fire Department shall perform the duties
set down by the Fire Chief and as ordered by the superior officer.
   (B)   Each member shall, at each alarm of fire, report to their respective
fire station. All members are required to respond to the fire to staff
apparatus until all apparatus have been manned and are on the road. Officers
may stop at the scene of the alarm if it is on their way to the firehouse and
no higher ranking officer has established command at the scene. In all cases
where a firefighter has reported to the scene rather than the firehouse he or
she shall immediately report to his or her superior.
   (C)   At an alarm of fire, incident, or assignment, no member shall leave
his or her post of duty unless so ordered by his or her superior officer.
   (D)   After an alarm of fire, incident, or assignment, every member shall be
expected to return with the apparatus and shall not leave the Fire Department
until attendance has been recorded by the officer in charge and dismissal
given.
   (E)   Members may be excused from returning to the Fire Department by
obtaining permission from the officer in charge of their respective apparatus.
   (F)   Under no condition shall a firefighter leave the apparatus or any
position in which he or she may have been placed while on duty without the
permission of the officer in command.
   (G)   No member of the Fire Department shall drive any department vehicle
apparatus except the regularly appointed driver unless directed to by the
superior officer or the Fire Chief, and then only in the case of emergency.
   (H)   No member of the Fire Department shall be permitted to tamper with or
fix or repair any apparatus unless directed to by the superior officer of the
Fire Chief, and then only in the case of emergency.
   (I)   No person shall be allowed to enter any fire station or handle any
apparatus or implements belonging to the Fire Department unless accompanied by
an active member of the Fire Department.
   (J)   No apparatus shall be permitted to leave the confines of the township
in case of a fire in an adjacent or neighboring municipality unless a prior
mutual aid agreement has been negotiated or they are dispatched by the Camden
County Communications Center.
   (K)   All requests for repairs or supplies for the Fire Department shall be
presented to the Battalion Chief for approval, via the chain of command. In
case any apparatus shall become so disabled that immediate repairs are
necessary, the officer operating such apparatus shall immediately report the
condition to the Battalion Chief, via the chain of command, who shall have same
repaired in accordance with the applicable state and municipal regulations.
(Ord. 311-17, passed 12-27-17; Am. Ord. 411-22, passed 10-24-22; Am. Ord. 426-
23, passed 4-23-23)

38.20
GENERAL PROVISIONS RELATING TO BOARDS AND COMMITTEES
§ 32.001 APPLICABILITY.
   The provisions of this subchapter shall not apply in any instance where a
state statute is in conflict herewith.
('74 Code, § 12-3) (Ord. 340-1986, passed 10-14-86)
§ 32.002 ABSENTEEISM.
   (A)   The member of any board or committee appointed by the Mayor and/or the
Mayor and Township Committee may be removed for absenteeism, and the vacancy
created by such removal shall be filled in the same manner as originally
appointed.
   (B)   While retaining all other rights of removal existing by reason of
statutory provision or common law, it is the intent of this subchapter to
include absenteeism as a cause for removal.
   (C)   For the purposes of this subchapter, any member who fails to attend
three successive regularly scheduled meetings or work sessions or more than
one-third of the regularly scheduled meetings or work sessions in any three-
month period, whichever is greater, may be removed from such board or
committee.
('74 Code, § 12-1) (Ord. 340-1986, passed 10-14-86)
§ 32.003 ATTENDANCE REPORTS; HEARING TO DETERMINE EXCUSABLE ABSENCES.
   (A)   It shall be the responsibility of the chairperson of each board and
committee to send monthly reports of attendance to the Township Clerk. When the
reports reflect absences equal to the number prescribed in §
32.002(C), ten-day written notices shall be sent to the member(s) by the Clerk
of the intent to remove.
   (B)   Upon request of the member to be removed, a hearing will be held by
the Mayor and Township Committee to determine whether the absences were
excusable.
('74 Code, § 12-2) (Ord. 340-1986, passed 10-14-86)
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE
§ 32.015 CREATION OF AN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby created an Economic Development Committee which will be
known as the “Economic Development Committee of the Township of Voorhees.” This
Committee shall be advisory to the Township Committee and shall consist of not
less than five or more than seven members. A Township Committee member and the
Township Economic & Community Development Coordinator shall be appointed in
addition to the five to seven members that make up the Committee.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.016 APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERMS; MEETINGS.
   (A)   The term of office of Committee members shall be for three years; and
terms shall be arranged so that approximately one-third of the total membership
shall expire each year.
   (B)    The Committee members shall be appointed by the Township Committee
and consist of two or more township residents and two or more township business
owners. A Township Committee member and the Economic and Community Development
Coordinator shall also be appointed to serve in addition to the appointed
Committee members.
   (C)   The Economic Development Committee shall meet on a schedule devised by
its members, but not less than four times each year.
   (D)   A quorum shall consist of a majority of the whole number of members.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.017 OFFICERS.
   The Committee shall organize annually by the election of one of its members
as Chairman. The Committee shall, also, elect a Vice Chairman. The Committee
shall, also, appoint a Secretary, which Secretary need not be a member of the
Committee.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.018 DUTIES.
    The Economic Development Committee shall have and perform the following
duties to the extent it deems necessary:
   (A)   The development of plans and programs to encourage the expansion and
strengthening of existing business and commercial enterprises in the township
consistent with the best interests of the township as a whole.
   (B)   The development of plans and programs which will attract new business
and commercial enterprises to the township which are in the best interests of
the township as a whole.
   (C)   The investigation, analysis and submission of regular reports to the
Township Committee on any obstacles to the expansion of the industrial and
commercial tax base of the township.
   (D)   The making of recommendations to the Township Committee regarding any
ways or means by which the township can assist in meeting the needs of any
development deemed appropriate.
   (E)    The Economic Development Committee may participate in appropriate
county and regional economic development activities.
   (F)   The Economic Development Committee shall develop ways and means of
promoting and attracting the township’s economic development assets for
industry, resort/tourism, transportation, governmental and other potential
economic interests.
   (G)   The Economic Development Committee shall not exercise any power of
condemnation and shall not be authorized to pledge the credit of the township
or to create any debt against the township or in any manner act as the agent of
the township, except as specifically authorized by resolution of the Township
Committee.
   (H)   The Economic Development Committee is authorized to expend such monies
as may be appropriated for its use in the annual township budget to carry out
the purposes of the Committee as hereinabove set forth.
   (I)   The Economic Development Committee shall make an annual report to the
Mayor and Township Committee setting forth, in detail, its operations and
transactions for the preceding 12 months. The Committee shall keep complete and
accurate records of its accounts, shall not exceed its budget and monies
received from the township and shall be expended only for the purposes for
which they have been appropriated.
   (J)   The Economic Development Committee shall inquire into, survey and
publicize the extent, advantages and utility of the vacant lands of the
municipality, whether municipality-owned or otherwise; classify the vacant
lands according to their adaptability for economic development; study and
analyze the surrounding municipalities with a view to ascertaining the
opportunities for the economic development of the municipality; advertise the
economic advantages and opportunities of the municipality and the availability
of real estate within the municipality for economic development; encourage
accomplish the economic development of the township. The Committee may also
confer with the Tax Assessor and study the tax structure with a view toward
making recommendations to reduce the tax burden of the municipality.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.019 OATH OF OFFICE.
   Each member and officer of the Committee shall, before assuming office, take
and subscribe an oath that he or she will faithfully and impartially discharge
the duties of his or her office.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.020 BYLAWS; COMPENSATION.
    To effectuate its purposes, the Economic Development Committee shall have
the power to adopt suitable bylaws for the management of its affairs. The
members and officers of the Committee shall serve without compensation, but
each shall receive their actual disbursements for expenses incurred in
performing their respective duties.
(Ord. 308-17, passed 9-11-17; Am. Ord. 419-2023, passed 2-13-23)
ENVIRONMENTAL COMMISSION
§ 32.035 COMMISSION ESTABLISHED; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby created in the Township an Environmental Commission,
pursuant to N.J.S.A. 40:56A-1 et seq., with the membership, powers, duties and
responsibilities hereafter set forth in this subchapter. The Commission is
established to research, discuss and recommend to the township various
environmental programs and policies that would facilitate the protection and
improvement of the environment, efficient management of natural resources,
promote a sustainable community, and enhance the aesthetic appearance of the
township, as well as the protection, development or use of natural resources
located within the township.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.036 MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION; CHAIRMAN; ALTERNATE MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Commission shall consist of five regular members, one alternate
member, and one Township Committee Liaison which shall be the appointed Class
III Planning Board member, all appointed by the Mayor and approved by Township
Committee. One regular member shall also be a member of the Township Planning
Board, one regular member shall also be a member of the Township Zoning Board,
and all regular and alternate members shall be residents of the township.
   (B)   All members of the Commission shall serve without compensation.
   (C)   The Mayor shall designate one regular member to serve as Chairman and
presiding officer of the Commission.
   (D)   The alternate member shall be designated at the time of their
appointment as Alternate No. 1. An alternate member may participate in
discussions of the proceedings but may not vote except in the absence or
disqualification of a regular member. A vote shall not be delayed in order that
a regular member may vote instead of an alternate member.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)   
§ 32.037 TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   (A)   Regular members. Initially, the regular member who is not the Planning
Liaison or the Zoning Liaison shall be appointed for, in regard to the first, a
one-year term, and in regard to the second, a two-year term. Thereafter, each
appointment shall be for a three-year term and until the appointment and
qualification of such member's successor. The term of the Planning Liaison
shall coincide with such person's term on the Township Planning Board. The term
of the Zoning Liaison shall coincide with such person's term on the Zoning
Board. A vacancy on the Commission occurring other than by expiration of a term
shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original
appointment.
   (B)   Alternate member. The term of the alternate member shall be for two
years. A vacancy occurring otherwise than by expiration of term shall be filled
by the Township Committee for the unexpired term only.
   (C)   Township Committee Liaison. The term of the Township Committee Liaison
shall be for one year.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.038 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Mayor or Township Committee may remove any regular member of the
Commission for cause, on written charges served upon the member and after a
public hearing thereon, at which the member shall be entitled to be heard in
person or through counsel.
   (B)   An alternate member, after public hearing if he or she requests one,
may be removed by the Township Committee for cause.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.039 RECORDS TO BE KEPT; ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Commission shall keep records of its meetings and activities and shall
make an annual report to the Township Committee, which report shall be
comprehensive and detailed, covering operations, receipts, disbursements and
expenditures for the full year, and shall be shared with the Township Zoning
Board and the Township Planning Board.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.040 MEETINGS AND RECORDS TO BE OPEN TO PUBLIC; CONFLICTS.
   (A)   The meetings of the Commission shall be subject to the Open Public
Meetings Act, and its records shall be considered public documents.
   (B)   No member or alternate member may act on any matter, or participate in
the discussions or deliberation on any matter in which he or she, either
directly or indirectly, has any personal or financial interest or other
conflict of interest (as determined, if necessary within the sole discretion of
the Township Solicitor).
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.041 APPROPRIATION; ADDITIONAL EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   (1)    Funds for the expenses incurred by the Commission shall be
appropriated through (a) the referring board (hereafter defined) for a referred
application (hereafter defined) or (b) if a project (hereafter defined) is
referred by Township Committee, then from such funds appropriated by the
township for such project.
      (2)   Annually, the Commission shall deliver to the Township Committee an
annual budget (for the calendar year then commencing) covering all anticipated
costs and expenses of the Commission, including all costs associated with any
planned or proposed projects during the budget year, which budget shall be used
by the Township Committee in setting the appropriation for such year; provided,
however, that the appropriation shall be within the sole discretion of Township
Committee.
   (B)   (1)   The Commission may appoint a secretary, who may be an employee
of the township and who need not be a member of the Commission.
      (2)   The Commission may, in connection with any (a) project, with the
approval of Township Committee, or (b) referred application, with the approval
of the referring board, engage an engineer or such other professionals or
consultants as the Commission deems necessary to advise it on matters pertinent
to the project or referred application; provided, however, that the costs, fees
and expenses associated with same have been approved by the referring board or
Township Committee, as applicable.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.042 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
   (A)   At the request of the Planning Board, compile and keep an index of all
open areas, publicly or privately owned, including open marshlands, swamps and
other wetlands, compile information on the proper use of such areas, and
recommend to the Planning Board plans and programs concerning open space to
include in the Township Master Plan and recommend to the Township Committee
plans and programs for the development and use of such areas.
   (B)   At the request of Township Committee, or at the recommendation by the
Commission and approval of Township Committee, undertake the following
projects:
      (1)   Plan and implement programs that inform the public about local
conservation programs, promote conservation of and develop the quality of the
environmental resources of the Township and promote the preservation and
protection of natural resources such as water, flora and fauna.
      (2)   Manage donated or purchased lands for conservation purposes and
operate conservation programs.
      (3)   Act as the coordinating agency for the Township on conservation
matters and as a liaison between the Township and regional, county, state and
federal agencies and programs.
      (4)   Study and make recommendations concerning open space preservation,
water resources management, air pollution control, solid waste management,
noise control, soil and landscape protection, environmental appearance, marine
resources and protection of flora and fauna.
      (5)   The powers and duties in §
32.044 (with respect to acquisition of property). Research, make application
for and promote grants and other financial assistance programs which can
provide funding to the Commission and/or the Township to fulfill the
Commission's duties pursuant to this section.
      (6)   Develop, manage and/or support any subcommittee of the Commission
(e.g., Sustainable Voorhees) or other group in furtherance of the purpose of
the Commission.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.043 APPLICATIONS FOR DEVELOPMENT.
   On request of either the Planning Board or the Zoning Board (the “referring
board”) in connection with an application (“a referred application”), the
Commission shall review the referred application and provide its advice to the
referring board, which advice shall be conveyed through the Zoning Liaison or
the Planning Liaison, as applicable, by way of written report from the
Commission and, if required by the referring board, the testimony of the Zoning
Liaison or the Planning Liaison, as applicable, at the hearing on the referred
application to explain the written report. The written report must be submitted
to the referring board's secretary (or, in the absence of a secretary, the
chairperson) no later than seven business days before the scheduled public
hearing on such referred application.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 35-00, passed 12-28-00; Am. Ord. 417-
2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.044 ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY.
   (A)   The Commission, subject to the approval of the Township Committee, may
acquire property, both real and personal, in the name of the Township by gift,
purchase, grant, bequest, devise or lease for any of its purposes and shall
administer the same for such purposes subject to the terms of the conveyance or
gift. The funds for any such purchase shall be within the limits of and
supplied from the funds appropriated to the Commission. All provisions of the
Local Lands and Buildings Law shall apply with respect to such acquisition and
administration of real property by the Commission.
   (B)    Any such acquisition may be to acquire the fee or any lesser
interest, development right, easement (including conservation easement),
covenant or other contractual right (including conveyance on conditions or with
limitations or reversions), as may be necessary to acquire, maintain, improve,
protect, limit the future use of or otherwise conserve and properly utilize
open spaces and other land and water areas of the Township.
   (C)   Any such acquisition must be in furtherance of the purposes of the
Commission, including but not limited to, for use as living museums, sites for
scientific study, areas for teaching of natural history and conservation,
places of historic or prehistoric interest and scenic beauty and habitat for
rare and endangered plants and animals, passive recreation uses and open space.
(Ord. 957-99, passed 11-8-99; Am. Ord. 417-2023, passed 2-13-23)
TOWNSHIP MARKETING COUNCIL
§ 32.055 ESTABLISHMENT.
   In order to actively promote the development of commercial and other
nonresidential property within the Township, with the intent of maximizing the
tax ratable base for the Township with minimal strain on Township and local and
regional school district resources, there is hereby established and created by
this subchapter a committee to be known as the Marketing Council of the
Township.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.056 MEMBERSHIP; CHAIRPERSON AND VICE CHAIRPERSON.
   (A)   The Council shall consist of seven voting members and one nonvoting
member. Five members shall be residents of the Township, one member shall be
the Mayor or another member of Township Committee as designated by the Mayor,
and one member shall be the Aide to the Mayor. In addition to the foregoing,
one member of the Township Committee shall be appointed by the Township
Committee each year as a nonvoting member of the Council.
   (B)   The Aide to the Mayor shall be the Chairperson of the Council. The
Council shall select from the voting members a Vice Chairperson who shall
perform the duties of Chairperson in the Chairperson's absence. The Vice
Chairperson shall serve for a period of one year.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.057 APPOINTMENTS; QUALIFICATIONS; TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   (A)   The members of the Council shall be appointed by the Township
Committee. Each member shall be a citizen of the United States of America and a
qualified voter of the state of New Jersey. Each member shall be appointed for
a term of three years. Vacancies on the Council for any cause shall be filled
for the unexpired term of the member being so replaced. Members shall serve for
their respective terms and until their successors are thereafter appointed and
qualified.
   (B)   Each member shall be chosen with a view to his or her qualifications
and fitness for service, shall have had experience in industry and commerce,
and shall be conversant with the economic needs and facilities of the Township.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.058 COMPENSATION.
   The members and officers of the Council shall serve without compensation,
but each shall receive actual disbursements for expenses in performing his or
her duties.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.059 QUORUM.
   A majority of the voting members shall constitute a quorum of the Council.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.060 ADOPTION OF BYLAWS.
   To effectuate its purposes, the Council shall have the power to adopt
suitable bylaws for the management of its affairs and to determine the duties
of its members, subject to §
32.061 below.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.061 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Council shall have all powers and duties necessary to accomplish the
purposes stated in §
32.055 above, including, but not limited to, the following: inquire into,
survey and publicize the extent, advantages and utility of the vacant lands of
the Township, whether Township owned or otherwise; classify the vacant lands
according to their adaptability for economic development; study and analyze the
surrounding municipalities with a view to ascertaining the opportunities for
the economic development of the Township; advertise the economic advantages and
opportunities of the Township and the availability of real estate within the
Township for economic development; encourage and accomplish the economic
development of the Township; and any other related activities that will promote
the economic development of the Township. The Council may also confer with the
Tax Assessor and study the tax structure with a view toward making
recommendations to reduce the tax burden of the Township. The Council shall
also periodically review and recommend changes to the Township zoning
regulations, development regulations and procedures, and the Township Master
Plan if, in the exercise of their reasonable business judgment, such changes
would be necessary to accomplish the goals of the Township as enumerated in §
32.055. The Council shall take advantage of all medium in existence to help
accomplish such goals, including, but not limited to, the internet.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
§ 32.062 LIMITATION ON POWERS; MONTHLY REPORT.
   The Council shall not have any powers other than those set forth in this
subchapter and specifically shall have no power to pledge the credit of the
Township or to enter into contracts or to otherwise create debts, except as
herein authorized, and shall operate within the appropriation made by the
Township Committee in its annual budget. The Council shall make a monthly
report to the Township Committee, setting forth in detail its operations and
recommendations covering the preceding calendar month.
(Ord. 873-98, passed 5-11-98)
RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.115 CREATION; MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.
   There is hereby created a Recreation Advisory Board consisting of members to
be appointed by the Township Committee. All members of the Board shall be
residents of the Township. The membership of the Recreation Advisory Board
shall include five at-large members as well as a representative of each
recreational group operating in the Township that has been approved by the at-
large members of this Board and approved by Township Committee, in a list,
which shall be reviewed by the at-large members at least annually, identified
as the "Approved Voorhees Recreational Groups List". The appointment of the
members of the Approved Recreational Groups (the "Liaisons") to this Board
shall be based upon the recommendation of the applicable Approved Recreational
Group and approved by the Township Committeeperson who is the Director of Parks
and Recreation. No member of the Board shall receive any compensation for his
or her services.
('74 Code, § 21-1) (Ord. 538-1991, passed 3-11-91; Am. Ord. 49-04, passed 5-10-
04; Am. Ord. 418-2023, passed 2-13-23)
§ 32.116 TERMS; VACANCIES.
   The terms of the six recreational group members of the Board shall be for
one year. All at-large members shall serve for a term of three years. Members
of the Board are subject to removal at any time for any reason that the
Voorhees Code recognizes, after a hearing, by the Mayor and Township Committee.
Any vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of any unexpired term in the same
manner as the original appointment.
('74 Code, § 21-2) (Ord. 538-1991, passed 3-11-91; Am. Ord. 49-04, passed 5-10-
04)
§ 32.117 ADVISORY MEMBERS.
   The Township Committee may appoint two nonvoting advisory members to the
Recreation Advisory Board, one such member representing Voorhees CER or the
Voorhees School District, and one such member from the Township parks and
recreation staff. Such advisory members shall serve for terms of one year.
('74 Code, § 21-3) (Ord. 538-1991, passed 3-11-91; Am. Ord. 49-04, passed 5-10-
04)
§ 32.118 PURPOSE; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board is established to assist in the development and implementation of
recreation programs for residents of the Township. In order to carry out these
purposes, the Board shall have the following functions:
   (A)   To promote the recreational programs and facilities of the Township.
   (B)   To plan and implement local recreational programs available to
residents of all ages within the Township, and to inform the public about such
programs.
   (C)   To recommend to the Mayor and Township Committee plans and programs
for the use of Township recreational facilities, including playgrounds.
   (D)   To act as a coordinating agency to the community on recreational
matters and as a liaison between the Township and local, regional, county or
state recreational groups, public or private.
   (E)   To recommend to the Township Committee the establishment of
recreational programs to meet the needs of the residents of the Township.
('74 Code, § 21-4) (Ord. 538-1991, passed 3-11-91; Am. Ord. 49-04, passed 5-10-
04)
§ 32.119 LIAISON OFFICER.
   The member of the Township Committee who is the head of parks and recreation
in the Township shall be the liaison officer between the Township Committee and
the Recreation Advisory Board.
('74 Code, § 21-5) (Ord. 538-1991, passed 3-11-91; Am. Ord. 49-04, passed 5-10-
04)
AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT GRIEVANCE COMMITTEE
§ 32.130 APPOINTMENT OF COMMITTEE AND RELATED OFFICIALS.
   In January of each year at its reorganization meeting, the Township
Committee shall appoint by resolution the following positions:
   (A)   ADA Compliance Officer. The ADA Compliance Officer shall be a Township
employee who holds a confidential position within the Township and who is a
department head or higher level employee.
   (B)   Township Committee Liaison to the ADA Grievance Committee. The Liaison
shall be a member of Township Committee. This person shall work closely with
the ADA Compliance Officer to ensure that the procedures approved pursuant to
this subchapter are followed.
   (C)   ADA Grievance Committee. The committee shall be comprised of five
members, including the ADA Compliance Officer, the Township Committee Liaison
to the ADA Grievance Committee and three members appointed by the Township
Committee. The Township Committee shall take reasonable steps to appoint
members to the ADA Grievance Committee who are employees of the Township and
who have the background, education or experience that would reasonably suit
them for a position on a committee which may be asked to review issues dealing
with facilities, service and access to qualified individuals with disabilities.
(Ord. 847-97, passed 11-10-97)
Cross-reference:
   ADA procedures adopted by reference, see §
38.50
§ 32.131 COMMITTEE DUTIES AND MEMBERSHIP.
   The ADA Grievance Committee will be subject to the following duties and
conditions:
   (A)   The ADA Grievance Committee will meet as and when deemed necessary by
the ADA Compliance Officer; provided, however, that the ADA Grievance Committee
must meet within 15 days after all information necessary to evaluate a notice
of claim received as provided in the procedures adopted pursuant to this
subchapter and §
38.50. The ADA Compliance Officer will provide at least three days prior
written notice to all members of the ADA Grievance Committee of the date, time
and place of any meeting of the ADA Grievance Committee.
   (B)   A quorum of the ADA Grievance Committee shall be three members. All
decisions of the ADA Grievance Committee must be by the affirmative vote of a
majority of the members. All decisions of the ADA Grievance Committee must be
in writing and certified by the ADA Compliance Officer. Minutes of all meetings
of the ADA Grievance Committee will be maintained by the ADA Compliance
Officer. The ADA Compliance Officer is charged with the safekeeping of all
records with respect to the activities of the ADA Grievance Committee.
   (C)   If any member of the ADA Grievance Committee is disqualified from
participating in the review of any claim made under the ADA pursuant to the
procedures adopted under this subchapter and § 38.50 because of a conflict of
interest or a perceived conflict of interest, such person shall be counted for
purposes of determining whether a quorum is present, but such person shall not
participate in any discussions or review of any materials and shall not vote on
the matter. If for any reason the ADA Grievance Committee shall be unable,
because of a conflict, to have at least three members able to participate in
any review of a claim made under the ADA pursuant to the approved procedures,
temporary representatives to the ADA Grievance Committee shall be appointed by
the Township Committee by special resolution at the request of the Township
Committee Liaison to the ADA Grievance Committee.
(Ord. 847-97, passed 11-10-97)
   BOARD OF HEALTH
§ 32.140 BOARD ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby created in the Township a Board of Health, pursuant to
N.J.S.A. 26:3-1 et seq., with the membership, powers, duties and
responsibilities hereafter set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.141 MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION; CHAIRMAN; ALTERNATE MEMBERS.
   (A)   The Board shall consist of five members, appointed by the Township
Committee.
   (B)   All members of the Board shall serve without compensation, except that
each member shall be entitled to $2 for each meeting of the Board that such
member attends. Such compensation shall be paid in the same manner as Township
Committee members are paid for their services.
   (C)   The Board shall designate one regular member to serve as Chairman and
presiding officer of the Board.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.142 TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   (A)   Initially, two members shall be appointed to serve until December 31,
2000, two members shall be appointed to serve until December 31, 2001 and one
member shall be appointed to serve until December 31, 2002. Thereafter, each
appointment shall be for a three year term and until the appointment and
qualification of such member's successor. A vacancy on the Board occurring
other than by expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term in
the same manner as the original appointment for the remainder of the term of
the vacating member.
   (B)   All members of the Board shall be residents of the Township.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.143 REMOVAL OF MEMBERS.
   The Township Committee may remove any member of the Board for cause, on
written charges served upon the member and after a public hearing thereon, at
which the member shall be entitled to be heard in person or through counsel.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.144 RECORDS TO BE KEPT; ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Board shall keep records of its meetings and activities and shall make
an annual report to the Township Committee, which report shall be comprehensive
and detailed, covering operations, receipts, disbursements and expenditures for
the full year.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.145 MEETINGS AND RECORDS TO BE OPEN TO PUBLIC; CONFLICTS.
   (A)   The meetings of the Board shall be subject to the Open Public Meetings
Act, and its records shall be considered public documents. In January of each
year, the Board shall hold an organization meeting at which it shall designate
the dates, times and places of its meetings for the ensuing fiscal year, except
for the year 2000, which organizational meeting shall occur as soon as
practicable after the initial members of the Board are appointed by Township
Committee. At least one regular meeting shall occur in each year. Special
meetings may be called at any time by the Chairman of the Board or the State
Department of Health. Notice of all regular and special meetings shall be
published as required under the Open Public Meetings Act.
   (B)   No member may act on any matter, or participate in the discussions or
deliberation on any matter in which she, either directly or indirectly, has any
personal or financial interest.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00)
§ 32.146 APPROPRIATION; ADDITIONAL EMPLOYEES.
   (A)   The Township Committee, each year, shall appropriate funds for the
expenses incurred by the Board. Such appropriation shall be sufficient to
permit the Board to fulfill its duties and powers under §
32.147 below and for the expenses of the Board. Annually, the Board shall
deliver to the Township Committee an annual budget (for the calendar year then
commencing) covering all anticipated costs and expenses of the Board, which
budget shall be used by the Township Committee in setting the appropriation for
such year. In addition, the Township shall also make any and all emergency
appropriations in accordance with N.J.S.A. 26:3-44.
   (B)   The Board may appoint a secretary, who may be an employee of the
Township and who need not be a member of the Board; provided, however, that the
costs, fees and expenses with respect to such secretary must fall within the
limits of funds appropriated by the Township Committee to the Board each year.
All provisions of the Local Public Contracts Law shall apply with respect to
the hiring of any consultants or professionals by the Board.
   (C)   The Board shall appoint the Camden County Health Officer and the
Public Officer for the purpose of carrying out the responsibilities established
by Ordinance No. 318-18 to act as its general agents for the enforcement of its
ordinances and sanitary laws of the State of New Jersey. All costs and expenses
with respect to the services of the Health Officers shall be paid for by the
township from the appropriations for the Board. All provisions of N.J.S.A. 26:
3-1 et seq. applicable to health officers shall apply to the Health Officers
appointed by the Board.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00; Am. Ord. 10-2000, passed 4-10-00; Am. Ord. 322-
18, passed 3-5-18)
§ 32.147 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board shall have the following powers and duties within the
jurisdictional limits of the Township:
   (A)   All powers and duties enumerated in N.J.S.A. 26:3-31.
   (B)   The powers set forth in N.J.S.A. 26:3-32 through 26:3-34.
   (C)   Preparation of an annual report in accordance with N.J.S.A. 26:3-35.
   (D)   Enforcement of N.J.S.A. 26:3-45 through 26:3-62.
   (E)   The code established and adopted by this subchapter is described and
commonly known as the “Public Health Nuisance Code of New Jersey (1953)” which
is hereby adopted in its entirety.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00; Am. Ord. 322-18, passed 3-5-18)
§ 32.148 RULE ADOPTION.
   The Board shall adopt such ordinances and rules as it shall deem appropriate
in accordance with N.J.S.A. 26:3-64 through 26:3-69.5, including all
procedures, processes and penalties for the violation of any health ordinance
or code in accordance with N.J.S.A. 26:3-70 through 26:3-82.
(Ord. 08-2000, passed 3-13-00
CITIZENS CULTURAL AND DIVERSITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE
§ 32.160 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE.
   In order to foster positive human relations through education, encouragement
of greater respect and understanding between people and the recognition of the
racial, ethnic, religious and cultural diversity and promote tolerance and
mutual respect between all persons within the municipality, there is hereby
established and created by this chapter a committee to be known as the Citizens
Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee of the Township of Voorhees.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07)
§ 32.161 MEMBERSHIP; CHAIRPERSON AND VICE CHAIRPERSON.
   (A)   The Committee so created shall consist of 14 regular members and one
member who shall also be a member of the Township Committee and shall have the
powers hereinafter enumerated.
   (B)   The Citizens Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee shall select
from its regular members one member to serve as its Chairperson and one member
to serve as Vice Chairperson to serve for a period of one year.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07; Am. Ord. 205-12, passed 2-13-12)
§ 32.162 APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   (A)   The members of the Citizens Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee
shall be appointed by the Township Committee. Each member shall be a citizen of
the United States of America, a qualified voter of the State of New Jersey.
Each member shall be appointed for a term of three years; provided, however,
that the schedule of appointments and terms thereof shall be staggered as
follows: four members shall be appointed to serve until December 31, 2012; five
members shall be appointed to serve until December 31, 2013; and five members
shall be appointed to serve until December 31, 2014. Thereafter, each
appointment shall be for a three-year term until the appointment and
qualification of such member’s successor. A vacancy on the Committee occurring
other than by expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term in
the same manner as the original appointment for the remainder of the term of
the vacating member.
   (B)   All members of the Committee shall be residents of the Township.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07; Am. Ord. 205-12, passed 2-13-12)
§ 32.163 COMPENSATION.
   The members and officers of the Committee shall serve without compensation
but each shall receive actual disbursement for expenses in performing his or
her duties.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07)
§ 32.164 QUORUM.
   A majority of the voting members shall constitute a quorum of the Committee.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07)
§ 32.165 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Citizens Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee shall have all powers
and duties necessary to accomplish the purpose stated in §
32.160, including the following:
   (A)   To provide a forum that will encourage input from our culturally
diverse citizen group for reviewing and establishing our Township’s vision.
   (B)   To advocate and assist in the development of continuing educational
programs for Township Committee and staff that will lead to a greater
understanding of the value of a diverse community to the governance process.
   (C)   To provide outreach to the community in an effort to place the issue
of diversity before our citizens in a positive manner.
   (D)   To identify obstacles that impede access to Township government for
all of our community’s diverse members.
   (E)   To provide for the review and recommendation of culturally diverse
members for consideration of appointment to the Committee’s various boards,
commissions and task forces.
   (F)   To hold regular public meetings at least once a month and to keep a
written record of its proceedings, which shall be a public record.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07)
§ 32.166 LIMITATION ON POWERS; ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Committee shall not have any powers other than those set forth herein
and specifically shall have no power to pledge the credit of the municipality
or to enter into contracts or to otherwise create debts, except as herein
authorized, and shall operate within the appropriation made by Township
Committee in its annual budget. The Committee shall make annual reports to the
municipality during December of each year, setting forth in detail its
operations and recommendations covering the preceding 12 months.
(Ord. 97-07, passed 2-26-07)
VOORHEES ART COMMISSION
§ 32.170 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE.
   In order to provide a space for local artists to express their creativity
and share their artistic gifts with the community, there is hereby established
and created by this subchapter a commission to be known as the Voorhees Art
Commission of the Township of Voorhees, which may also be known as the Voorhees
Arts Council.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.171 MEMBERSHIP; CHAIRPERSON AND VICE CHAIRPERSON.
   (A)   The Commission so created shall consist of five regular members and
one non-voting member who shall also be a member of the Township Committee and
shall have the powers hereinafter enumerated.
   (B)   The Commission shall select from its regular members one member to
serve as its Chairperson, one member to serve as Vice Chairperson, and one
member to serve as its Secretary to serve for a period of one year.
   (C)   The Commission may be served by an advisory board of non-voting
members who do not need to be residents of the Township of Voorhees.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.172 APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS; TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.
   (A)   The members of the Voorhees Art Commission shall be appointed by the
Township Committee. Each member shall be a citizen of the United States of
America and a qualified voter of the State of New Jersey. Each member shall be
appointed for a term of three years; provided, however, that the schedule of
appointments and terms thereof shall be staggered as follows: one member shall
be appointed to serve until December 31, 2022; two members shall be appointed
to serve until December 31, 2023; and two members shall be appointed to serve
until December 31, 2024. Thereafter, each appointment shall be for a three-year
term until the appointment and qualification of such member’s successor. A
vacancy on the Commission occurring other than by expiration of a term shall be
filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment
for the remainder of the term of the vacating member.
   (B)   All members of the Commission shall be residents of the Township. This
does not apply to the advisory board of non-voting members.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.173 COMPENSATION.
   The members and officers of the Commission shall serve without compensation,
but each shall receive actual disbursement for expenses in performing his or
her duties.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.174 QUORUM.
   A majority of the voting members shall constitute a quorum of the
Commission.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.175 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Voorhees Art Commission shall have all powers and duties necessary to
accomplish the purpose stated in §
32.170, including the following:
   (A)   To provide a forum that will encourage input from our art community
for reviewing and establishing our township’s vision;
   (B)   To advocate and assist in the development of continuing educational
programs for the Township Committee and staff that will lead to a greater
understanding of the value of a growing art community;
   (C)   To hold regular public meetings at least every other month and to keep
a written record of its proceedings, which shall be a public record; and
   (D)   Recommend to the Township Committee and implement and supervise
programs, exhibits, galleries events to display and/or sell art.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.176 ADOPTION OF BYLAWS.
   To effectuate its purposes, the Commission shall have the power to adopt
suitable bylaws for the management of its affairs and to determine the duties
of its members, subject to §
32.177 below.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
§ 32.177 LIMITATION ON POWERS; ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Commission shall not have any powers other than those set forth herein
and specifically shall have no power to pledge the credit of the municipality
or to enter into contracts or to otherwise create debts, except as herein
authorized, and shall operate within the appropriation made by Township
Committee in its annual budget. The Commission shall make annual reports to the
municipality during December of each year, setting forth in detail its
operations and recommendations covering the preceding 12 months.
(Ord. 396-22, passed 2-28-22)
CHAPTER 33: MUNICIPAL COURT
Section
General Provisions
   
33.01   Establishment of court
   
33.02   Jurisdiction and administration
Public Defender
   
33.20   Office established; duties
   
33.21   Indigent defendants
   
33.22   Application fee; fee for services rendered
   
33.23   Funds collected
GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 33.01 ESTABLISHMENT OF COURT.
   There shall be established in the Township of Voorhees a municipal court to
be known as the “Municipal Court of the Township of Voorhees.”
§ 33.02 JURISDICTION AND ADMINISTRATION.
   The Municipal Court shall be administered and shall have all jurisdiction
power and authority as provided in N.J.S.A. 2B:12-1 et seq.
PUBLIC DEFENDER
§ 33.20 OFFICE ESTABLISHED; DUTIES.
   (A)   The office of Public Defender is hereby established.
   (B)   The Township Public Defender shall represent all indigent defendants
in Municipal Court, except in those cases of temporary unavailability or
conflict of interest, who have been charged with an offense in Municipal Court
and are entitled to representation pursuant to N.J.S.A. 2B:24-1 et seq. All
necessary services and facilities of representation, including both expert and
lay investigation and testimony, as well as other preparation, shall be
provided in every case. The Municipal Public Defender shall be responsible for
handling all phases of the defense, including but not limited to discovery,
pre-trial and post-trial hearings, motions, removals to federal district court
and other collateral functions reasonably related to the defense. As used in
this division, POST-TRIAL HEARING shall not include de novo appeals to Superior
Court. It shall also be the responsibility of the Township Public Defender to
verify eligibility of applicants, verify payment of application fees by the
indigent defendants, and to create and use such forms as are necessary to
assure the eligibility of such applicants and the payment of their application
fees.
   (C)   The Municipal Public Defender shall receive compensation as
established through the Township salary ordinance. The Municipal Public
Defender may submit a detailed invoice covering fees and costs expended by him
or her for services which may be required beyond attendance at regular
Municipal Court sessions, which additional fees and charges shall be paid at
the same hourly rate as the hourly rate in effect for the Township Solicitor at
that time out of the funds collected pursuant to this subchapter.
   (D)   The Municipal Public Defender shall appear only at those times and on
those dates that his or her services are required in order to represent
indigent defendants as determined by the Municipal Court Judge.
('74 Code, § 20-1) (Ord. 694-94, passed 3-14-94; Am. Ord. 876-98, passed 6-8-
98)
§ 33.21 INDIGENT DEFENDANTS.
   Each defendant in the Municipal Court who is entitled to be represented by a
Municipal Public Defender pursuant to N.J.S.A. 2B:24-2 shall be represented by
the Municipal Public Defender, provided that such defendant does not have the
present financial ability to secure competent legal representation.
('74 Code, § 20-2) (Ord. 876-98, passed 6-8-98)
§ 33.22 APPLICATION FEE; FEE FOR SERVICES RENDERED.
   (A)   The Municipal Court Clerk shall collect from the indigent defendant an
application fee of $200. In accordance with guidelines promulgated by the New
Jersey Supreme Court, the Judge of the Municipal Court may waive a portion or
all of the required application fee, only if the court determines in its
discretion, upon a clear and convincing showing by the applicant, that the
application fee represents an unreasonable burden on the person seeking
representation. The Municipal Court may also permit the indigent defendant to
pay the application fee over a specific period of time not to exceed four
months. A default or failure in making payments of the application fee shall
disqualify the indigent defendant from receiving services by the Municipal
Public Defender.
   (B)   If the indigent defendant has or reasonably expects to have means to
meet some part, though not all, of the costs of the services rendered, the
defendant shall, in addition to the application fee, be required to reimburse
the Township, either by a single payment or in installments in such amount as
he can reasonably be expected to pay; but no default or failure to make
payments to meet some part, or all, of the costs of the services rendered,
shall affect or reduce the rendering of services by the Municipal Public
Defender. The Township shall have a lien on any property to which the indigent
defendant shall have or acquire an interest in for an amount equal to the
reasonable value of the services rendered to the indigent defendant pursuant to
this chapter, as calculated at the same rate as the Office of the Public
Defender bills the Township pursuant to §
33.20 at that time. To effectuate such a lien for the Township, the Township
Solicitor shall file a notice setting forth services rendered to the indigent
defendant and the reasonable value thereof with the Clerk of the Superior
Court. The filing of the notice with the Clerk of the Superior Court shall
constitute a lien on the property for a period of ten years from the date of
filing, unless discharged sooner, and, except for such time limitations, shall
have the force and effect of a judgment. Within ten days after the filing of
the notice, the Municipal Attorney shall send by certified mail or serve
personally a copy of the notice with a statement of the date of the filing to
or upon the indigent defendant at the indigent defendant's last known address.
('74 Code, § 20-2) (Ord. 876-98, passed 6-8-98)
§ 33.23 FUNDS COLLECTED.
   Funds collected by the Municipal Court Clerk for application fees and fees
for services rendered that are paid by indigent defendants shall be deposited
into a dedicated fund administered by the Chief Financial Officer of the
Township. Such funds shall be used exclusively to meet the costs incurred in
providing the services of Municipal Public Defender including, when required,
expert and lay investigation and testimony. Beginning on January 1, 1999, those
funds collected which exceed more than 25% of the amount which the Municipality
expended during the prior year for providing the services of the Municipal
Public Defender shall be forwarded to the Criminal Disposition and Review
Collection Fund administered by the Victims of Crime Compensation Board.
'74 Code, § 20-3) (Ord. 876-98, passed 6-8-98)
CHAPTER 34: FINANCE AND TAXATION
Section
